After the United States passed the new GENIUS Act , the law aims to make clearer and safer rules for digital currencies. South Korea‚Äôs ruling party doesn‚Äôt want to be left behind. They have just announced plans to fast-track fresh laws covering Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. Why Speeding Up Crypto Laws Matters In a recent tweet post, Bitcoin Archive noted that South Korea‚Äôs ruling party plans to speed up crypto laws after the GENIUS Act in the U.S. The ruling Democratic Party believes faster legislation can protect users better while encouraging new business opportunities. Officials say the GENIUS Act proves big economies now take crypto seriously, and South Korea wants to lead, not fall behind. headline: The Trump administration's crypto report is due today, but it may not arrive

The House of Representatives passed three major crypto bills, with one, the GENIUS Act , now headed directly to President Trump‚Äôs desk. The other two are bound for Senate review. This has left the digital assets market hanging in the middle of the bull run. US eyes Bitcoin reserve The US legislation wave positions the United States as the ‚Äúcrypto capital of the world.‚Äù The Trump administration‚Äôs first official blueprint for crypto policy reportedly took months, led by the Working Group on Digital Assets, co-led by David Sacks and Bo Hines. While the final contents are still under wraps, reports suggest it will include sweeping proposals, from establishing a strategic Bitcoin reserve , a national digital asset stockpile, with tough new national security controls on illicit finance and sanctions evasion. The working group‚Äôs original task was to deliver a federal stablecoin framework, but that got handled by Congress last week with the passage of the GENIUS Act. Meanwhile, Capitol Hill remains active, and the Senate Banking Committee is preparing to release its much-anticipated digital asset market structure draft after a delay last week. The report mentioned that Chairman Tim Scott confirmed a markup will likely follow the August recess. Over at Senate Agriculture, Brian Quintenz suddenly disappeared from the CFTC chair nominating vote roster. Critics eye Trump‚Äôs crypto ties All of this policy momentum has triggered a wave of bullish sentiment among investors. The crypto market recently breached the $4 trillion mark. Many of those positions have since been trimmed, which has added to a modest pullback to the $118,000 zone of BTC. However, most of the institutional re-engagement began after Circle‚Äôs blockbuster IPO last month. As the Trump administration pushes harder into crypto, critics are sounding alarms. Some warn that the industry‚Äôs murky structure and lack of transparency could make it a ground for corruption or foreign influence. Token holdings within Trump-affiliated projects have prompted scrutiny. As of now, the GENIUS Act may offer some early consumer safeguards for stablecoins, yet there are many regulatory gaps. headline: Bitcoin Market: Navigating the Crucial Consolidation Phase Towards $115K
summary: BitcoinWorld Bitcoin Market: Navigating the Crucial Consolidation Phase Towards $115K The cryptocurrency world has been on a rollercoaster ride, with Bitcoin leading the charge to exhilarating new all-time highs. Yet, as the dust settles, the Bitcoin market finds itself in a period of consolidation. This isn‚Äôt a sign of weakness, but rather a healthy recalibration after an intense rally. Understanding this phase is crucial for any investor looking to navigate the volatile yet promising landscape of digital assets. What exactly does this consolidation mean for Bitcoin‚Äôs future, and could a retest of the significant $115,000 level truly be on the horizon? Decoding the Bitcoin Market ‚Äòs Current State: The Glassnode Perspective To truly grasp the dynamics at play in the current Bitcoin market , we turn to on-chain analytics firm Glassnode, renowned for its deep insights into blockchain data. Their latest findings paint a clear picture of shifting momentum following Bitcoin‚Äôs monumental surge. One of the key metrics highlighted by Glassnode is the Realized Profit to Loss Ratio (RPLR). This indicator measures the ratio of realized profits to realized losses on the network, offering a window into the profitability of coins spent by investors. Historically, an RPLR above 1 indicates that more profits are being taken than losses, a common occurrence during bull markets. The Shift from 3.9 to 2.6: Glassnode reported a significant drop in the RPLR from a peak of 3.9 to 2.6. What does this mean? A higher RPLR (like 3.9) suggests aggressive profit-taking, often seen near market tops as investors capitalize on gains. The subsequent decline to 2.6 indicates a cooling off in this intense profit-taking behavior. While still above 1 (meaning profits are still being realized), the reduced ratio signals that the frenetic pace of selling for profit has subsided. Signaling Cooling Profitability: This drop doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean losses are accumulating, but rather that the rate at which profits are being locked in has slowed. It suggests that fewer participants are selling their holdings at substantial gains, or that the gains themselves are becoming less extreme. This often precedes or accompanies a period of market consolidation. Investors Adjusting to Range-Bound Conditions: Glassnode explicitly stated that investors are now adjusting to ‚Äòrange-bound conditions.‚Äô This implies that the market is no longer in a strong directional trend (up or down) but is instead trading within a defined price range. In such an environment, the focus shifts from chasing parabolic gains to identifying support and resistance levels, and potentially accumulating at lower prices within the range. This data from Glassnode provides a fundamental understanding of investor sentiment and behavior, suggesting a move from aggressive profit-taking to a more strategic, patient approach within the Bitcoin market . Understanding Range-Bound Conditions in the Bitcoin Market : What Does it Mean for You? When analysts talk about the Bitcoin market being ‚Äòrange-bound,‚Äô it‚Äôs a critical concept for investors to grasp. Unlike the exhilarating surges of a bull run or the sharp declines of a bear market, a range-bound market is characterized by prices trading consistently between a specific high (resistance) and a specific low (support) for an extended period. Think of it like a ping-pong ball bouncing between two walls. The price might fluctuate significantly within that range, but it doesn‚Äôt break out decisively in either direction. For investors, this phase presents both unique challenges and opportunities: Challenges: Frustration for Momentum Traders: Those who thrive on rapid price appreciation may find range-bound conditions frustrating, as large, quick gains become less frequent. Increased Volatility within the Range: While the overall trend is flat, intra-range volatility can still be high, leading to potential ‚Äòshake-outs‚Äô where weak hands are forced to sell. Uncertainty: The lack of a clear directional trend can lead to indecision and analysis paralysis among investors. Opportunities: Accumulation Phases: Smart investors often view consolidation as an ideal time to ‚Äòdollar-cost average‚Äô (DCA) into their positions, buying at various points within the range to lower their average entry price. Strategic Trading: Experienced traders can profit by buying near the support level and selling near the resistance level, though this requires precise execution and risk management. Healthy Market Reset: Consolidation allows the market to digest recent gains, shake out speculative froth, and build a stronger foundation for the next upward move. It prevents markets from becoming overheated and unsustainable. Recognizing and adapting to range-bound conditions is vital for long-term success in the Bitcoin market . It calls for patience, a strategic mindset, and a focus on long-term value rather than short-term fluctuations. The Allure of $115,000: A Key Liquidity Hub for the Bitcoin Market In the world of trading, ‚Äòliquidity‚Äô refers to how easily an asset can be bought or sold without affecting its price. High liquidity means there are many buyers and sellers, allowing for smooth transactions. When we talk about a ‚Äòkey liquidity point‚Äô like $115,000 for the Bitcoin market , it signifies a price level where a substantial amount of buy and sell orders are concentrated. Popular trader Daan Crypto Trades, whose insights are often shared by Cointelegraph, has highlighted $115,000 as precisely such a critical juncture. His observation that ‚Äòpositions are building in this range‚Äô is highly significant. Here‚Äôs why: Concentration of Orders: A liquidity point like $115,000 suggests that many market participants have placed their buy or sell orders around this price. These could be stop-loss orders, take-profit orders, or new entry orders. Potential Magnet for Price: Price often tends to gravitate towards areas of high liquidity. If there‚Äôs a large cluster of buy orders below the current price, it can act as a strong support level, attracting price downwards before bouncing. Conversely, a large cluster of sell orders above can act as resistance. Fueling the Next Price Move: When price approaches a significant liquidity zone, it can trigger a cascade of orders. For instance, if Bitcoin dips towards $115,000 and hits a large volume of buy orders, it could absorb selling pressure and provide the necessary ‚Äòfuel‚Äô for a powerful rebound. Conversely, if it breaks below with conviction, it could trigger stop-losses and lead to a further decline until the next liquidity zone is found. Psychological Significance: Round numbers and previously important technical levels often gain psychological significance. While $115,000 might not be a round number, it could represent a confluence of technical indicators or a price point where a large number of investors feel comfortable entering or exiting. The accumulation of positions around $115,000 suggests that this level is being closely watched by a significant portion of the Bitcoin market . Its interaction with this price point could indeed dictate the direction and momentum of Bitcoin‚Äôs next major move. Is a $115K Retest Inevitable for the Bitcoin Market ? Examining the Possibility The concept of a ‚Äòretest‚Äô is fundamental in technical analysis, especially in dynamic markets like Bitcoin. A retest occurs when a price level, once broken (either as resistance turning into support, or vice versa), is revisited by the price to confirm its new role. Given the building liquidity at $115,000, the question arises: is a retest of this level for the Bitcoin market inevitable? While ‚Äòinevitable‚Äô is a strong word in financial markets, the possibility of a $115K retest is certainly high, driven by several factors: Support/Resistance Flip: If $115,000 was a significant resistance level that Bitcoin recently broke above, a retest would involve the price dipping back to confirm this level as new support. This is a classic pattern that strengthens the bullish case if the support holds. Liquidity Absorption: As discussed, large liquidity pools act as magnets. A retest allows the market to ‚Äòabsorb‚Äô the resting buy orders at that level. If these orders are strong enough, they can halt the downward momentum and initiate a bounce. Market Psychology and Price Discovery: After a rapid ascent, markets often need to consolidate and find a stable footing. A retest can be part of this price discovery process, allowing investors to establish a new base of confidence before the next leg up. It also provides a second chance for those who missed the initial breakout to enter. Historical Precedent: Bitcoin‚Äôs history is replete with examples of retests after significant price movements or breakouts from consolidation patterns. These retests often serve to validate the strength of a new trend or the importance of a particular price level. However, it‚Äôs important to note that a retest isn‚Äôt guaranteed, nor is its outcome. If the Bitcoin market finds strong buying pressure before reaching $115,000, it might move upwards directly. Conversely, if selling pressure is too strong, a retest could fail, leading to a break below $115,000 and a search for lower support levels. Traders and investors will be closely watching the volume and price action around this critical level to gauge its strength. Navigating Investor Psychology Amidst Bitcoin Market Consolidation Beyond the charts and on-chain data, understanding investor psychology is paramount, especially during periods of consolidation in the Bitcoin market . While a bull run is often fueled by euphoria and FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out), and a bear market by fear and capitulation, consolidation brings its own unique psychological challenges. During these range-bound phases, patience becomes a virtue, and emotional discipline is tested: Patience vs. Panic: The lack of immediate upward movement can lead to impatience. Some investors might panic and sell, fearing the rally is over. Others might chase small, short-term gains, only to be caught in whipsaws. Long-term holders, however, often view consolidation as an opportunity to accumulate more, understanding that these periods are necessary for sustainable growth. The Role of Long-Term Holders vs. Short-Term Traders: Glassnode‚Äôs data often distinguishes between these groups. During consolidation, long-term holders (HODLers) tend to remain steadfast, even adding to their positions. Short-term traders, on the other hand, might try to scalp profits within the range, but face higher risks. Avoiding Emotional Decisions: The absence of clear direction can lead to indecision and emotional trading. It‚Äôs crucial to stick to a pre-defined investment strategy, whether it‚Äôs dollar-cost averaging, setting clear entry/exit points, or simply holding. Chasing every rumour or reacting to every minor price swing can lead to significant losses. FUD and Noise: Consolidation periods often coincide with increased FUD (Fear, Uncertainty, Doubt) in the media, as commentators search for explanations for the stalled price. Discerning legitimate news from speculative noise is vital to avoid making irrational decisions. Ultimately, successful navigation of the Bitcoin market during consolidation requires a calm temperament, a clear understanding of your investment goals, and a commitment to your long-term strategy. It‚Äôs a time for reflection and strategic planning, not impulsive reactions. Beyond the Charts: Other Factors Influencing the Bitcoin Market While on-chain metrics and technical analysis provide invaluable insights, the Bitcoin market is also profoundly influenced by a broader array of macroeconomic, regulatory, and technological factors. Understanding these external forces can provide a more holistic view of Bitcoin‚Äôs potential trajectory. Macroeconomic Trends: Inflation and Interest Rates: Bitcoin is often seen as a hedge against inflation. If global inflation persists, or if central banks continue aggressive interest rate hikes, it can influence investor appetite for risk assets like Bitcoin. Global Economic Stability: Geopolitical events, recessions, or significant shifts in global economic policy can either drive investors towards perceived safe havens like Bitcoin or away from speculative assets. Regulatory Developments: Government Stance: Regulatory clarity (or lack thereof) from major economies can significantly impact institutional adoption and mainstream acceptance. Positive regulations (like spot Bitcoin ETFs) can be massive catalysts, while restrictive measures can create headwinds. Compliance: The evolving landscape of AML (Anti-Money Laundering) and KYC (Know Your Customer) regulations affects how exchanges and financial institutions interact with crypto, influencing liquidity and accessibility. Institutional Adoption: Corporate Treasuries: The increasing trend of corporations adding Bitcoin to their balance sheets signifies growing confidence and provides a steady demand source for the Bitcoin market . Financial Products: The success and expansion of Bitcoin ETFs, futures, and other regulated financial products provide new avenues for traditional investors to gain exposure, increasing market depth and legitimacy. Technological Advancements: Network Upgrades: While less frequent for Bitcoin than for other blockchains, any significant protocol upgrades or scaling solutions (like the Lightning Network) can enhance its utility and appeal. Security: Continuous improvements in network security and wallet technology bolster trust in the asset. Mining Dynamics: Halving Events: The quadrennial Bitcoin halving, which reduces the supply of new Bitcoin, has historically been a strong bullish catalyst, though its effects are typically felt over months, not days. Mining Difficulty and Hash Rate: These metrics indicate the health and security of the network. A robust and growing hash rate suggests strong miner participation and confidence. By considering these broader influences alongside on-chain data, investors can develop a more comprehensive and robust strategy for navigating the complexities of the Bitcoin market . Challenges and Opportunities in the Current Bitcoin Market The current consolidation phase in the Bitcoin market , while healthy, presents a unique set of challenges and, crucially, a wealth of opportunities for discerning investors. Understanding both sides of this coin is essential for making informed decisions. Challenges: Extended Sideways Movement: Consolidation can sometimes be prolonged, testing the patience of investors hoping for quick returns. A lengthy sideways trend can lead to ‚Äòcrypto fatigue‚Äô and potentially drive some investors away. Potential for Deeper Corrections: While the market is consolidating, there‚Äôs always a risk that the established support level might break, leading to a sharper correction downwards. This could be triggered by negative news, macroeconomic shocks, or simply a lack of sustained buying pressure. Increased Volatility Within the Range: Even within a defined range, Bitcoin‚Äôs price can experience significant swings. These ‚Äòwhipsaws‚Äô can liquidate over-leveraged positions and create uncertainty, making short-term trading particularly risky. Sentiment Shifts: Prolonged consolidation can lead to a shift in market sentiment from bullish enthusiasm to skepticism or even bearishness, which can further dampen price action. Opportunities: Accumulation Phases: For long-term investors, consolidation periods are prime opportunities to accumulate Bitcoin at potentially more favorable prices. Dollar-cost averaging (DCA) becomes a highly effective strategy during these times, allowing investors to build their positions gradually without trying to ‚Äòtime the bottom.‚Äô Identifying Strong Hands: During consolidation, weaker hands (those with low conviction or high leverage) tend to get shaken out. The coins are then transferred to stronger, long-term holders, which strengthens the market‚Äôs foundation for future rallies. Technical Re-evaluation: This period allows traders to refine their technical analysis, identify new support and resistance levels, and prepare for the eventual breakout. It‚Äôs a time for strategy, not impulse. Fundamental Research: With less focus on day-to-day price swings, investors can dedicate more time to researching Bitcoin‚Äôs underlying technology, ecosystem developments, and broader adoption trends, reinforcing their conviction. Reduced FOMO: The absence of parabolic price action reduces the pressure of FOMO, allowing investors to make more rational decisions based on analysis rather than emotion. The current Bitcoin market phase is a test of patience and conviction. While it presents challenges, the opportunities for strategic positioning and long-term growth are substantial for those who understand its dynamics. Actionable Insights for Engaging with the Bitcoin Market Navigating a consolidating Bitcoin market requires a disciplined approach. Here are some actionable insights to help you make informed decisions during this crucial phase: Embrace Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA): Instead of trying to time the market, commit to investing a fixed amount of money into Bitcoin at regular intervals (e.g., weekly or monthly). This strategy reduces the impact of price volatility and allows you to accumulate more Bitcoin when prices are lower within the range. Prioritize Risk Management: Define Your Risk Tolerance: Understand how much you‚Äôre willing to lose and never invest more than you can afford. Set Stop-Losses: If you‚Äôre actively trading, use stop-loss orders to limit potential losses if the price moves against your position. Avoid Excessive Leverage: Highly leveraged positions are extremely risky during volatile consolidation periods and can lead to rapid liquidations. Conduct Thorough Research: Use this calmer period to deepen your understanding of Bitcoin‚Äôs fundamentals, its role in the global financial system, and its long-term value proposition. Follow reputable analysts, read whitepapers, and understand the technology. Monitor Key On-Chain Metrics: Keep an eye on data from Glassnode and other on-chain analytics firms. Metrics like Realized Profit/Loss Ratio, Net Unrealized Profit/Loss (NUPL), and Exchange Flows can provide early signals of shifts in market sentiment or investor behavior within the Bitcoin market . Identify Key Technical Levels: Pay attention to established support and resistance zones. The $115,000 liquidity point highlighted by Daan Crypto Trades is a prime example. Understanding these levels can help you identify potential entry or exit points. Cultivate Patience: The most powerful tool in a consolidating market is often patience. Avoid impulsive decisions driven by fear or greed. Markets move in cycles, and consolidation is a natural, healthy part of Bitcoin‚Äôs journey. Diversify (Wisely): While Bitcoin might be your primary focus, consider a well-diversified crypto portfolio if it aligns with your risk profile. However, avoid over-diversification into highly speculative altcoins during uncertain periods. By adopting these actionable insights, you can transform the current consolidation phase from a period of anxiety into an opportunity for strategic growth and enhanced understanding of the Bitcoin market . Glassnode‚Äôs data on the Realized Profit to Loss Ratio clearly indicates a shift from aggressive profit-taking to more range-bound conditions, signaling investor adjustment. While the path ahead may involve a retest of this key level, such a reconfirmation could strengthen Bitcoin‚Äôs foundation for future growth. For investors, this period demands patience, strategic accumulation, and a keen eye on both on-chain metrics and broader market factors. Understanding these dynamics is not just about predicting the next price move, but about building resilience and conviction in your investment strategy within the ever-evolving Bitcoin market . headline: Spot Bitcoin ETFs See $131 Million Outflow After Record Inflows
summary: Spot Bitcoin ETFs recorded a net outflow of $131.35 million on Monday, ending a 12-day streak that saw $6.6 billion in inflows, as investors paused to lock in gains after Bitcoin‚Äôs recent price rally. According to SoSoValue, ARK Invest‚Äôs ARKB led the outflows, shedding $77.46 million, followed by Grayscale‚Äôs GBTC with $36.75 million and Fidelity‚Äôs FBTC with $12.75 million. Bitwise‚Äôs BITB and VanEck‚Äôs HODL also recorded smaller outflows of $1.91 million and $2.48 million, respectively, while BlackRock‚Äôs IBIT, the largest Bitcoin ETF with $86.16 billion in assets under management, reported no inflows or outflows for the day. Profit-Taking After a Strong Rally Despite the pause, cumulative net inflows across all spot Bitcoin ETFs remain strong at $54.62 billion, with total net assets now standing at $151.60 billion, accounting for 6.52% of Bitcoin‚Äôs total market capitalization. Many experts are suggesting that the withdrawals are part of a routine correction after a strong upward move, as institutions rebalance their positions to manage risk and secure profits following significant inflows earlier in July. On July 10 and 11, Bitcoin ETFs recorded $1.18 billion and $1.03 billion in daily inflows, marking the first time in history that two consecutive days brought in over a billion dollars each into Bitcoin funds. Ether ETFs Continue Strong Inflow Streak While Bitcoin-base investment funds saw a brief pause, spot Ether ETFs extended their inflow streak to 12 consecutive days , recording $296.59 million in net inflows on Monday. This pushed the cumulative net inflow for Ether ETFs to $7.78 billion, highlighting rising institutional interest in Ethereum-based products. Last Wednesday marked a record day for Ether ETFs, which saw $726.74 million in daily inflows, the highest since their launch, followed by $602.02 million on Thursday. The consistent demand for Ether ETFs reflects increasing confidence in Ethereum‚Äôs long-term utility as the network continues to attract activity around tokenization and decentralized applications, positioning Ether products to capture growing institutional allocations alongside Bitcoin funds in the expanding crypto investment landscape.
